Award.AwardTitle: Colloidal Superparticles from Self-Assembly of Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Superparticles are nanoparticle assemblies in the form of colloidal particles. They exhibit physical and chemical properties inherited from their nanoparticle constituents as well as the collective properties of these constituents induced from coupling effects. Under the support of the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program at NSF, Prof. Cao and his research group aim to: (1) develop size-controlled synthesis of colloidal superparticles, (2) explore the principles that govern the constituent-packing and surface morphology of colloidal superparticles, and (3) investigate the formation of colloidal superparticles from binary nanoparticle constituents.

The goal of this project is to develop synthetic methodology for making monodispersed colloidal superparticles potentially useful for new manufacturing technology for next generation industries. The research effort is integrated with educational activities for training graduate and undergraduate students in multidisciplinary nanoscience and nanotechnology research areas. This project also includes outreach activities to promote the interests of high school students in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is to develop new fundamental understandings for the establishment of a new nanoscale manufacturing technology for next generation industry.  This new manufacturing technology is based on colloidal superparticles—a class of new material building blocks in nanotechnology.  The resulting colloidal superparticle as building blocks allow for manufacturing macroscale materials from nanoscopic building blocks through cost-effective, roll-to-roll printing methods, which are important for a number of applications such as large-screen, energy-efficient LCDs and low-cost solar cells.  In addition, we have found that colloidal superparticles can be used as precursors for making metastable materials with high-energy crystal structures, which can be use as new types of hard coatings on cutting tools, superconductors and superinsulators.

The major research outcomes of this project are listed as follows. (1) We have developed two size-controlled synthesis of colloidal superparticles (i) from  nanoparticle micelles and (ii) from nanoparticle emulsions. (2) We have revealed that the formation of superparticles, and the constituent-packing configuration and surface morphology of the resulting superparticles are controlled by the interplay between the solvophobic and solvophilic interactions of nanoparticle assemblies, largely arisen from nanoparticle-nanoparticle interactions and nanoparticle-surfactant interactions, which are governed by synthesis factors including (i) the type of nanoparticle ligands, (ii) the density of these ligands, (iii) the concentration of guest molecules, (iv) the concentration of nanoparticles, (v) the type and composition of hydrophobic solvents, (vi) ionic strength of water solution, (vii) the volume ratio between hydrophobic solvents and water, (viii) the type and concentration of superfacticle surfactants, (ix) synthesis temperature, and (x) air-flow rate, which controlling the evaporation of organic solvents. (3) We have controllably synthesized binary superparticles composed of magnetite nanospheres and CdSe/CdS semiconductor nanorods and ternary superparticles with magnetite nanospheres, nanocubes, and CdSe/CdS semiconductor nanorods.  

The outcomes from the integrated education efforts include (1) training of two graduate students, three undergraduate students and two postdoctoral fellows in the multidisciplinary nanotechnology research areas which is important for future job creation and nation economy growth, (2) integrated activities with NSF-funded education programs (AGEP and REU), and (3) educational outreach hosting two high-school students for summer research.  

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2018
Modified by: Y. Charles Cao

This new manufacturing technology is based on colloidal superparticles—a class of new material building blocks in nanotechnology. The resulting colloidal superparticle as building blocks allow for manufacturing macroscale materials from nanoscopic building blocks through cost-effective, roll-to-roll printing methods, which are important for a number of applications such as large-screen, energy-efficient LCDs and low-cost solar cells. In addition, we have found that colloidal superparticles can be used as precursors for making metastable materials with high-energy crystal structures, which can be use as new types of hard coatings on cutting tools, superconductors and superinsulators. The major research outcomes of this project are listed as follows. (2) We have revealed that the formation of superparticles, and the constituent-packing configuration and surface morphology of the resulting superparticles are controlled by the interplay between the solvophobic and solvophilic interactions of nanoparticle assemblies, largely arisen from nanoparticle-nanoparticle interactions and nanoparticle-surfactant interactions, which are governed by synthesis factors including (i) the type of nanoparticle ligands, (ii) the density of these ligands, (iii) the concentration of guest molecules, (iv) the concentration of nanoparticles, (v) the type and composition of hydrophobic solvents, (vi) ionic strength of water solution, (vii) the volume ratio between hydrophobic solvents and water, (viii) the type and concentration of superfacticle surfactants, (ix) synthesis temperature, and (x) air-flow rate, which controlling the evaporation of organic solvents. The outcomes from the integrated education efforts include (1) training of two graduate students, three undergraduate students and two postdoctoral fellows in the multidisciplinary nanotechnology research areas which is important for future job creation and nation economy growth, (2) integrated activities with NSF-funded education programs (AGEP and REU), and (3) educational outreach hosting two high-school students for summer research.
